H0.text: They are always microscopic, which is why the objects from space that appear in meteor showers observed at certain times of the year are usually harmless.

H1.text: They are closer to the sun than to Earth, which is why meteor shower objects from space are usually harmless when observed from Earth at certain times of the year.

H2.text: They are made of soft, spongy materials, which is why meteor shower objects are usually harmless to observers on Earth.

H3.text: They burn up high in Earth's atmosphere, which is why meteor shower objects observed from Earth at certain times of year are usually harmless.

A4.text: These forces can cause loss of mass (ablation) or even complete disintegration of smaller objects, and objects with lower compressive strength can explode.

A5.text: Objects entering an atmosphere experience atmospheric drag... aerodynamic heatingâ€”caused mostly by compression of the air in front of the object, but also by drag.
